abstract.p: Dr Stanley F Wainapel letter says the varying blood pressure changes associated with visits to physicians' offices (Aug 1 article) reflect the varying responses of patients to the medical environment

block.p: The varying blood pressure changes associated with visits to physicians' offices (''When the White Coats Befuddle Doctors,'' Aug. 1) reflect the varying responses of patients to the medical environment. When fear or anxiety prevails, white-coat hypertension occurs; when comfort and confidence dominate, white-coat normotension results. As a physician who occasionally exchanges his white coat for a patient's gown, I find myself so at home in the medical environment that my blood pressure is, if anything, lower than normal.

The varying blood pressure changes associated with visits to physicians' offices (''When the White Coats Befuddle Doctors,'' Aug. 1) reflect the varying responses of patients to the medical environment. When fear or anxiety prevails, white-coat hypertension occurs; when comfort and confidence dominate, white-coat normotension results. As a physician who occasionally exchanges his white coat for a patient's gown, I find myself so at home in the medical environment that my blood pressure is, if anything, lower than normal.
Such variations call into question the existing data on the prevalence of hypertension as well as the parameters of its treatment.
DR. STANLEY F. WAINAPEL New York
